snippet: From her modest bungalow set back behind a lawn with a sycamore tree here, Stephanie Nordlinger is leading the counter-revolution against the great California tax revolt.   In 1978, California voters ignited a national anti-tax fever by passing a ...
lead_paragraph: From her modest bungalow set back behind a lawn with a sycamore tree here, Stephanie Nordlinger is leading the counter-revolution against the great California tax revolt. In 1978, California voters ignited a national anti-tax fever by passing a landslide amendment to the state Constitution known as Proposition 13. The immediate result was to halt the rapid tax increases that were driving some Californians out of their houses. But a long-term consequence has been enormous disparities between taxes paid by longtime residents and new buyers like Ms. Nordlinger, who say they are shouldering a tax burden that is unfair and unconstitutional.

headline.main: Tax Battle in California Reaches Supreme Court
